Fields.DialogueText: Archimede, report to the bridge... Archimede?
Fine, I will conduct the proper summons... BrRrRrR-brRrR-BrRrR!
Capitano, Archimede reporting as ordered.
Archimede, explain to me again why it's absolutely necessary I play this thing?
The kazoo, Capitano? On occasion I get lost in my work. I tend to tune out all sound, including voices. The kazoo is just unique enough to slip through my tunnel hearing.

Fields.MenuText: Right, I guess that makes sense. Very well.
I don't like it, Archimede. Isn't there something more professional I can use?
Your inattentiveness is not my problem, Archimede.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you for understanding, Capitano. Your playing isn't half bad.
I'll keep my eyes open. Besides, I'll tune out the kazoo eventually as well.
With all due respect, if you want me to continue my work, it is.
Moving on, have the system checks been completed?
They have. We are operational, although we are not running as efficiently as I would like.
How efficiently are we running?
Approximately 98.5 percent, Capitano... maybe 98.2?
*ALARM*
Morganas incoming. Drat, if only we were at 99.3 percent efficiency!
Very funny.
@BATTLE
Capitano, do you have a moment?
Yes, Archimede. What is it?
I have some concerns about the crew's performance - maintenance, in particular.
Speak plainly. Are they neglecting their duties?
Absolutely not! Their work is adequate and by the book.
Then what is your concern?
I have made several modifications that are, let's say, outside of the box. But the maintenance crew just keeps resetting them to standard.

Fields.MenuText: If they don't know your intentions, Archimede, then they are just performing their duties.
I'll speak with the maintenance CO and see what we can work out.
As they should be. They have manuals for a reason.

Fields.DialogueText: I guess I never did explain myself to them fully... or at all.
Grazie, Capitano. And thank you for trusting me.
Those manuals were outdated the day they were printed, Capitano.
If you are going to continue these modifications, the crew will need new manuals.
I don't know where we will get those.
You're going to write them. Then you will give briefings to the crew. I can't command a vessel my crew doesn't understand.
Aye, Capitano, I'll start right now.
*ALARM*
Or later.
@BATTLE
Attention, crew, we are under attack! Officers, to your stations! Do not give them an inch!
@BATTLE
All threats neutralized, Capitano.

Fields.MenuText: We may have taken a few hits. Are you all right?
I want crew accountability and a damage report.
Damage report?

Fields.DialogueText: Nothing I can't manage. Thanks for asking.
All stations reporting in. Superficial damage to the hull. Some nausea in the galley.
Superficial damage. Nothing to be overly concerned about.
Dents and scrapes don't bother you? I thought you were a perfectionist.
I'm not vain, Capitano. I'd look like an anglerfish if it would have me running at 100 percent.
You're an interesting one, Archimede.
And busy. I'm off to write those manuals.
Wait, don't you need these notes?
What notes?
These here - you were scribbling them down during the engagement.
Oh, no you can toss them, Capitano. That was just for fun.
Archimede, get dressed! That uniform needs some work.
Right, I was rushing. Sorry, this will only take a moment... Eureka!
Eureka?
Eureka! I've noticed some of the crew have really been missing their pets, so, behold!
What is THAT? Some kind of toy?
People have different kinds of pets, so I ran the full spectrum. A bird beak, bat ears, furball body and the comforting eyes of a porcelain doll.

Fields.MenuText: I... LOVE that thing! How many can you make?
That thing is evil. I feel it in my heart. Fresh out of hell, evil.
I have lost a piece of myself, in knowing that exists.

Fields.DialogueText: Just the one, unfortunately. The components were difficult to come by.
I only had enough material to make one, so don't worry about a legion, Dante.
Well I know who isn't getting this one-of-a-kind creation.
*ALARM*
I've already figured out how to make the eyes move.
Archimede.
Now if I could just get it to make noise. No, to speak!
Archimede?
These Morganas, they keep ruining my concentration...
@BATTLE
Capitano, have you had a moment to read my new manuals?
I've looked at them, yes.
And?

Fields.MenuText: They're too difficult to decipher, Archimede. They can't be just equations and theorems; they need to explain things.
All I did was look at it. I can't make sense of anything.
It's a mess. There is no order and no explanation.

Fields.DialogueText: Ha! You're right. I guess I was a little too excited.
Really? That doesn't bode well for the crew...
A mess is an exaggeration.
It's a first draft, and I'm not implying any wrongdoing.
*ALARM*
Then let's talk critiques after this distraction.
Absolutely.
@BATTLE
Archimede, do you have a second?
Certo! What's going on?
I just finished the second draft of your manuals.
Is it an improvement?

Fields.MenuText: An improvement? These are great! I've never seen such a turnaround.
They've improved a lot. I think they are ready to hand out.
Yes, we can hand these out to the crew.

Fields.DialogueText: Really? I was unsure, but thank you, Capitano!
Grazie, Capitano.
Yes, Capitano.
How do you plan on briefing the crew?
Briefing, Capitano? Well, I...
*ALARM*
Cattive Ragazze, Capitano! Unfortunately, we need to drop this discussion.
Delay, not drop, Archimede.
@BATTLE
Eureka! Eureka! I have solved the problem, Capitano.
Which problem is that?
Some of the crew have switched to a ten second toothbrushing instead of the recommended sixty seconds.
Can't say I approve of that.
I was constructing this compact engine for the turret when Seaman Erikson nearly knocked me out with a good morning.
That's when I thought, "Instead of a piston, I'll fasten on a toothbrush!" I can build enough for the whole crew.

Fields.MenuText: This engine was meant to control a turret? You've decreased its power, right?
Will this turret powered toothbrush damage their teeth?
So you plan on fixing the breath problem by knocking out their teeth?

Fields.DialogueText: I... was going to do that. Of course. Just let me make a note, Capitano.
Oh... sì... the teeth. This is why I value your critiques, Capitano.
No! It's not THAT powerful. Then again, it could use some revision.
*ALARM*
I'll mandate full minute oral hygiene in the meantime.
Sì, Capitano.
@BATTLE
Archimede, why haven't you briefed the crew on the new manuals yet?
I haven't? My apologies, of course. I'll move some experiments around and...
You're making excuses again. I'll schedule them for the end of the week.
But I need time to prepare!

Fields.MenuText: You're worrying too much. Just go over the manual and answer any questions.
You won't have any problems. It's just a simple briefing.
You've had plenty of time to prepare. This is an order.

Fields.DialogueText: You make it sound so easy...
Simple for you, maybe.
Respectfully, Capitano, you are ordering me to fail.
Archimede...
*ALARM*
Now here is a problem that's easy to resolve!
@BATTLE
Oh, I'm dizzy. Are we on course?
Yes, the crew is compensating. I heard your briefings went well?
They... did... they really did.

Fields.MenuText: The crew looks up to you. I knew you would do well.
The crew like your quirks. You shouldn't worry about speaking to them.
See, I told you. Easy.

Fields.DialogueText: Do they really? I never thought about that.
I was worried an hour straight of me would be too much for them.
I wouldn't say easy. But yes, I was capable.
So is the stress wearing off? Dizziness subsiding?
*ALARM*
I'm not dizzy from the briefings.
Should we deal with these Morganas?
@BATTLE
*deep breath*
BrRrRrRrR-BrRrRrR!
You kazooed me, Capitano?

Fields.MenuText: You haven't been yourself lately, Archimede. Is something wrong?
You've been having more dizzy spells than normal, haven't you?
Archimede, your performance has dropped recently.

Fields.DialogueText: Am I that obvious? Sì, something is wrong.
Sì, Capitano, I'm sorry. I am dealing with some complications.
Sì, Capitano. I will get better control of my faculties.
Would you tell me what the problem is?
Gnothi seauton.
"Know thyself"? You're not sure you do now?
*ALARM*
I really do underestimate that brain of yours, Capitano.
@BATTLE
Archimede, I'm sorry to pry, but please...
What's been troubling you?
... Do you know the story behind eureka, Capitano?

Fields.MenuText: Archimedes shouted it when he discovered buoyancy, didn't he?
Some Greek person in a bath shouted it. Something to do with displacement?
Yes. I met you, you yelled it at me, and you have continued to do so.

Fields.DialogueText: Sì, but people often miss the mark on an important detail.
Close enough. Well, there is a hidden message in there.
Oh... Capitano. No no, you're way off.
When Archimedes felt eureka, he wasn't just solving an equation. He was seeing through the physical, behind reality, into the cause of everything.
Go on?
He had been in a bath hundreds of times. The answer was always there. It wasn't some fluke, you see. All the greats do it.
How does all of that relate to you?
*ALARM*
I'm a fraud, Capitano. I have no right to shout eureka.
Archimede...
Morganas, Capitano, approaching fast.
@BATTLE
Archimede, we need to discuss your misconceptions about being a fraud.
It's true, Capitano. I realized it when I gave those briefings.
There isn't a single eureka in those manuals! Just cleverly rearranged, preconceived ideas.

Fields.MenuText: But they are innovations! There isn't a sub in the fleet, maybe the world, that runs like you.
They are still ideas no one thought of. Doesn't that count for anything?
So you haven't had your moment yet. Stop complaining.

Fields.DialogueText: They are not innovations. Just refinements.
Anyone who put their mind to it could have figured them out.
And what if I never have that moment?
I don't mean to sound arrogant, Capitano, but I am a Belle. I'm not the strongest or the fastest, but I thought, at the very least, I was clever. Now, I'm not sure.
*ALARM*
I'm at a loss for words.
I will still perform my duties to the highest standard, Capitano. I'll adjust to my new situation soon.
Don't turn sullen on me just yet, Archimede.
@BATTLE
Eureka!
That's not funny, Capitano.
I didn't mean it to be. Maybe I didn't peer beyond reality, but I did have an idea. You're bored.
I don't follow.
You haven't had a eureka because nothing is challenging you. Since I met you, you haven't faced a problem you couldn't solve in two seconds.
So now I'm too smart?

Fields.MenuText: Exactly.
I'm not the one who said it.
Just hold on and let me finish.

Fields.DialogueText: I think I see where you are going.
I walked into that.
Sì, Capitano.
Since I may not live long enough to see a problem you can't solve, we will just have to make one.
So how do we do that?
*ALARM*
That's on you, Archimede! This idea well is tapped dry. Back to things I understand.
Yes, Capitano!
@BATTLE
Archimede, sonar is reporting some unusual readings. What are you doing?
Listening, Capitano. I tweaked the sonar slightly... There's no threat. Go on, place your ear against the hull, too.
What is it? A ping?
Dolphins, Capitano! They're talking... well, not speaking, per se, but communicating.

Fields.MenuText: What are they saying?
Can you tell what they are ‘communicating?'
You had some crew members very worried, Archimede.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not really sure. I don't get many chances to just listen.
Not exactly. I would need more time to study and observe.
Sì, Capitano. I will do better at informing the crew in the future.
Hmmm. They sound like they are getting excited.
Sì... increased speed, lots of repetition, speaking over each other... they sound scared.
Morganas?
Capitano, permission to change course and engage if necessary?
Granted.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Capitano, I may have an idea for eureka. Before our next engagement with the Morganas, we should disable the sonar.
How will we target the Morganas? Especially once we submerge?
How indeed?

Fields.MenuText: We'll be blind, deaf, and in danger... It's exactly what you need.
I understand, but how dangerous will this be?
You are ready to put the lives of everyone on board at risk?

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, Capitano! I have full confidence in us and the crew.
Dangerous, Capitano, but we can do this.
Yes, Capitano. I won't let any harm come to them.
*ALARM*
Crew, this is your captain. You have all been briefed on Exercise Eureka. We are disabling the sonar for this engagement. Archimede?
Sì... I need everyone at your best. I will guide us through. Chiudere i boccaporti!
Batten down!
@BATTLE
No, no, no!
Archimede, grab hold of yourself! Did we take a bad hit? A breach?
Breaches? No, all contained. I need to check on the infirmary!

Fields.MenuText: Archimede, they are being taken care of. I need you here if you're going to help them.
You're not a physician. You need to help where you can now.
Archimede! You will remain at your post. That's an order.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, Capitano. What do I do?
But they... You're right. Yes, Capitano.
Yes, Capitano.
*ALARM*
Morganas!? Cattive Ragazze are the last things I need right now...
Unbelievable timing.
I'll send them all to the bottom of the ocean! ALL OF THEM!
Compose yourself, Archimede. No unnecessary damage.
Yes, Capitano.
@BATTLE
BrRrRrR-bRbRbRbRbR!
Archimede, you can't just avoid everyone... BrBrBrBr!
Sì, Capitano, reporting...

Fields.MenuText: I know you feel responsible for the attack, but you're not. We all knew what we were getting into.
If you need someone to blame, blame me. Stop sulking, please.
You screwed up. Now learn from it and move on.

Fields.DialogueText: Capitano, the crew believed I would protect them. That's what they thought they were getting into.
I can't blame you. I've tried. I'm the one who let everyone down.
I have learned... I've learned my place.
We'll take some time and revisit Exercise Eureka...
I'm terminating the exercise. I'm sorry, Capitano. It's not my decision to make, but I won't participate.
You're right, it's not your decision. However, I know better than to give an order like that.
Grazie, Capitano.
*ALARM*
You will not bury yourself in this incident. We still need you. We need your mind here. That I will make an order.
I understand, Capitano.
@BATTLE
Capitano, what is this?
That is a petition from the crew to continue the Eureka Exercise.
I thought we discussed this.
We did. We're discussing it again.
Capitano, I'm back to my senses, this isn't an emotional decision. I was arrogant, plain and simple. It's not worth the risk.
We were all arrogant, Archimede, and the rest of us haven't learned our lesson.
Why?
Your proposal was too good. If this works, you won't be the only one shouting eureka.

Fields.MenuText: You've inspired them and they would rather see it blow up in their faces than have it wither away.
You tempted them with the possibility of being a part of something amazing. They won't let that go easily.
We may not be Belles, but that doesn't mean we embrace the mundane.

Fields.DialogueText: You need to be a little foolish to be brave, I suppose.
I understand, believe me.
I've noticed.
*ALARM*
Do you need a decision now, Capitano?
No, but the crew would appreciate one soon.
I won't dawdle.
@BATTLE
Capitano, I've made a decision about Exercise Eureka.
If you're trying to build suspense, it's working.
I'll do it, but I have some conditions.
Go on.
Starting immediately, we will perform two lifeboat drills daily, rather than one. The sonar will be on standby, ready to activate at a moment's notice.
Agreed. Those are reasonable conditions.
Finally, if we are hit, we end the exercise immediately.

Fields.MenuText: You're tougher than that and so is the crew. Make it three hits and we have a deal.
We can't do that. They're committed to this, to the risk. Three hits, then we cancel.
No. They're risking their lives. They deserve a committed attempt. We take three hits before canceling.

Fields.DialogueText: I hope you're right.
I can't guarantee we would survive that.
Three hits. Sì, Capitano.
Then we have an accord?
Sì.
When will you start preparations?
I'll start right now.
*ALARM*
I'll start soon.
@BATTLE
Archimede, all stations are reporting in. We are officially on standby for Exercise Eureka.
They're ready, Capitano. I'm certain.
Are you? How's the balance?
I'm ready. I'm dizzy, for sure, but it's manageable. I feel like I ate a boulder.
Good, then it's not just me.
*ALARM*
This is it. Let's address the crew.

Fields.MenuText: This is it, everyone. Remember your posts, look out for each other. Let's make it happen.
Exercise Eureka is starting. Stay salty, and let's make history.
All hands, Exercise Eureka is a go. Let's let them have it!

Fields.DialogueText: This will not be a repeat of last time. We're ready now.
Grazie, everyone. Let's show them what we can do.
Mind your stations, follow my lead. We're coming out on top this time.
CHIUDERE I BOCCAPORTI!
Ha!
Batten down, you old sea dogs!
Sonar disengaged. Archimede, it's your show.
@BATTLE
EUREKA! EUREKA!
Archimede, sit down before you fall down.
We're not spinning to the bottom, right?
No, that's just you.
EUREKA! EUREKA!
Hahaha! Eureka!

Fields.MenuText: It worked! I don't know what happened, but we pulled it off.
You did it! What happened? How did you do it?
Archimede, take a breath. We're having a little trouble maintaining course.

Fields.DialogueText: It's amazing. The answer was right there in the water, the whole time.
It was indescribable, Capitano. I saw it, past the physical! I saw the answer.
Yes, of course. I'm sorry, I need a moment, Capitano.
*ALARM*
Relax, Archimede, we'll handle this.
You're certain, Capitano?
Yes. Wrap your mind around what happened. We're all dying to hear what you did.
@BATTLE
Archimede, spill it. How did you engage the Morgana without the sonar?
I'm still trying to figure out how to articulate it, Capitano, but basically, I felt them in the waves.
How is that possible? They weren't close enough to detect any wake.
That's just it, Capitano. Distance doesn't matter. The wake doesn't disappear... Its effect is still in the wave! Everything is!
Everything? Every ship? Every fish?
That energy is still there and it carries all the way to the shore.

Fields.MenuText: Are you telling me you could locate anything in the ocean?
That's amazing! This really paid off.
This sounds like science fiction.

Fields.DialogueText: If you can decipher the data, yes!
It was indescribable, Capitano. I saw it, past the physical, I saw the answer.
It does, doesn't it? It's incredible.
*ALARM*
Should we disengage the sonar?
Absolutely not! This is far from a confirmed science.
Then let's get back to it after this.
@BATTLE
I just finished reading your paper.
So... "Wave Language Theory?"
It did feel like the ocean was speaking to me. Too poetic?

Fields.MenuText: Not at all. I like it.
I preferred "Archimede Theory".
Not my favorite title, but I'm no writer.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Capitano.
We all share the credit, I couldn't name it after myself.
I'm no writer either. Hence the title.
So if I understood correctly, we can't use this theory now?
Not yet, not reliably. The amount of information to decipher is mind-boggling. It will be decades before we create a practical device.
Rome wasn't built in a day?
Exactly.
Well, regardless, we are well overdue for a celebration.
Celebration, Capitano? I'm a horrid party planner.
*ALARM*
That's why you're going to worry about the Morganas. Leave the celebration to me.
Yes, Capitano!
@BATTLE
Enjoying yourself?
I am! I've never seen the crew so...
... unpredictable.

Fields.MenuText: They're professionals at everything, especially celebrating.
The crew? And you learned that dancing where?
It may have been a mistake to disregard the alcohol ration.

Fields.DialogueText: Haha! Well put, Capitano.
It's an amalgam of what I learned watching them.
We all make mistakes, Capitano. At least you made a fun one.
Don't wear yourself out. The party's just started.
*ALARM*
This is the captain. Skeleton crew to your posts. Let's end this interruption quickly.
No problem, Capitano.
Do you need the music turned off?
... No, let those Cattive Ragazze hear it. Let them hear what they're missing.
Roger!
@BATTLE
Archimede!
Capitano, you made it down here.
I decided I could relieve myself for an hour or so.
Good! We were about to bring the record player up to the bridge.

Fields.MenuText: I'm relieved it's still playing. May I have this dance?
I realized, Archimede, that in all this time we've never shared a drink.

Fields.DialogueText: And you beat me to it. Why else would I lug a record player to the bridge? Let's go.
Poseidon curse us! Let's line ‘em up, Capitano.
I got lucky, having you as a partner. Thank you, Archimede.
Grazie, Capitano. Who would have guessed we would be this good together?
*ALARM*
Interrupted... of course.
No, the crew can handle it. This is long overdue.
It is.
